body: That's right. @wp8619
I've got the same error. Can anyone provide some hints?
Same problem here. I use the pre-trained VGG19 model converted from Caffe and increase the input size to 1000x1000. No problem if with cudnn, but not for cpu or cuda. Any idea?

You need to add workspace=2048 or 1024 in convolution symbol parameter.
Usually, larger input require larger workspace

Head gradient should have the same shape as output. The new `MakeLoss` layer can spare this effort and add a `grad_scale` to many unary and binary operators.

``` python
loss = outside_weight * mx.sym.smooth_l1(data=inside_weight * (data - target), scalar=1.0)
bbox_loss = mx.sym.MakeLoss(name='bbox_loss', data=loss, grad_scale=1.0)
```

I also got the same issue. A hacky solution that works for me is to edit `dmlc-core/make/dmlc.mk` and remove or commenting out the following lines:

```
ifndef NO_OPENMP
        DMLC_CFLAGS += -fopenmp
        DMLC_LDFLAGS += -fopenmp
endif
```

MNIST is too small. Communication cost dominates computation. 
Try inception
Is your array on cpu or gpu? You cannot directly access gpu memory

Seems you are loading a pre-trained model. For pretrained model, the shape info is in the symbol. If you like to finetune, you need to create model by using symbol, then initialize with `Load` initializer.

Could you post a minimum reproducing code snippet?
@hjk41

Could you post our code? Have you verified that it's the same with cudnn gpu version?
@antinucleon

Because Cudnn is using different algorithm. Different algorithm requires
different workspace

@piiswrong The machine I am using doesn't have CuDNN. Seems I made a mistake. Let me see whether we can fix by using mshadow, otherwise we need both CPU and GPU code for non-mshadow version.

The correct formula is d/dy_i y_i - \sum_j d/dy_j y_i y_j.
So we can do it with mshadow like this:
`m_out_data*(m_out_grad- broad_cast(reduce<sum>(m_out_grad*m_out_data)))`
actually, the current broadcast op will cause the reduce to be computed N times...
We can use tmp resource to calculate reduce first.
do we have to? The cudnn version doesn't seem to need that
Its in the CPU..
I do float\* A = buf.data().dptr_ and then tried to access A[0] ..but I always get 0 though it was a ndarray of ones.

you need to call buf.WaitToRead() before reading a ndarray

@antinucleon @pluskid
LGTM

```
def setup_lstm_model(ctx, batch_size, num_lstm_layer, seq_len, num_hidden, num_label, dropout=0.5, initializer=mx.initializer.Xavier()):
    lstm = lstm_unroll(batch_size, num_lstm_layer, seq_len, num_hidden, num_label, dropout)
    print "LSTM established"
    arg_names = lstm.list_arguments()
    input_shapes = {}
    input_shapes['data'] = (batch_size, seq_len, 1, 120, 160)
    input_shapes['softmax_label'] = (batch_size, seq_len)
    for i in range(num_lstm_layer):
        input_shapes['l%d_init_h' % i] = (batch_size, num_hidden)
        input_shapes['l%d_init_c' % i] = (batch_size, num_hidden)
        # input_shapes['l%d_i2h_weight' % i] = (batch_size, seq_len, num_hidden)
        # input_shapes['l%d_h2h_weight' % i] = (batch_size, seq_len, num_hidden)
        # input_shapes['l%d_i2h_bias' % i] = (batch_size, seq_len,)
        # input_shapes['l%d_h2h_bias' % i] = (batch_size, seq_len,)
    arg_shape, out_shape, aux_shape = lstm.infer_shape(**input_shapes)
    arg_arrays = [mx.nd.zeros(s, ctx) for s in arg_shape]
    args_grad = {}
    for shape, name in zip(arg_shape, arg_names):
        if name in ['softmax_label', 'data']: # input, output
            continue
        args_grad[name] = mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx)
    lstm_exec = lstm.bind(ctx=ctx, grad_req='add', args=arg_arrays , args_grad=args_grad, )
    # lstm_exec = lstm.simple_bind(ctx, grad_req='add')

    param_blocks = []
    arg_dict = dict(zip(arg_names, lstm_exec.arg_arrays))
    for i, name in enumerate(arg_names):
        if name in ['softmax_label', 'data']: # input, output
            continue
        # initializer(name, arg_dict[name])

        param_blocks.append( (i, arg_dict[name], args_grad[name], name) )

    out_dict = dict(zip(lstm.list_outputs(), lstm_exec.outputs))

    data = lstm_exec.arg_dict['data']
    label = lstm_exec.arg_dict['softmax_label']
    print "Setup finished"
    return LSTMModel(lstm_exec=lstm_exec, symbol=lstm, seq_data=data, seq_labels=label, param_blocks=param_blocks)
```

However, I tried to delete the third parameter in the binding, and then it worked...

If you want to use high level API, you must have a `Output` layer and indicate name for it, eg "softmax". Please refer `Custom Training Loop` chapter in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet-gtc-tutorial/blob/master/tutorial.ipynb

If there is no suitable Output symbol, you can calculate gradient in numpy, and set back in custom training loop while calling backward, eg: `exe.backward([top_grad])`
Just restart it
None that I know of. You are welcome to lead this. What do you want to use it for?
This issue was resolved by #2038.

Very nice! I would suggest an add on to our shape inference mechanism here: we should allow the user to attach shape information to a `Variable`. During shape inference, this information can be used. This is especially useful in the case when broadcasting is supported. Sometimes I have a parameter that should be broadcast through the samples in a mini-batch, if I use broad cast plus to construct a symbol, the shape inference will not be able to figure out the shape of that parameter purely based on the data shape.

Looks like another binary compatibility problem...
We have long been struggling with binary compatibility issues in MxNet.
Windows 10/8/7 and Windows servers need to have different binaries, and
some Windows 8 machines cannot run the binary built with Windows 10. We
haven't figured out why. Is it possible for you to build a binary from
source? It may help us pinpoint the problem.

still failed on osx
@mavenlin @antinucleon

@pluskid i didn't get your question. currently the shape inference is done by `BinaryBroadcastShape_`, which will determine the broadcast dimensions. One can also always use `symbol.Reshape` to make the broadcast performs correctly.
@Ldpe2G How about open another pr and let's see whether it can work around.

@mli For example, this currently works

``` python
import mxnet as mx

a = mx.sym.Variable('a')
b = mx.sym.Variable('b')
c = a+b
c.infer_shape(a=(10,20))
```

But if we replace `+` with boradcasting plus, will it still work? How is it going to infer the shape of `b` purely based on `a` for broadcasting? If you need a real scenario, there is this full LSTM implementation in acoustic model where a broadcasting elementwise multiplication is needed.
ok, I will try

the only way works is 

``` python
>>> d = mx.sym.BroadcastPlus(a,b)
>>> d.infer_shape(a=(10,20), b=(10,1))
```

so your use case is that the shape of `b` is unclear?

@mli in my use case, `b` is a parameter, while `a` is the data (or some hidden layer computed from the data). Our model or module are all based on the assumption that shape information are only from `provide_data` and `provide_label` from a `DataIter`, everything else should be able to be shape inferred. This works very well so far, except for this case. I think allowing the user to attach shape information to `Variable` sounds like a simple solution.

``` python
a = mx.sym.Variable('a')
b = mx.sym.Variable('b', shape=(1, 10))
c = mx.sym.BroadcastPlus(a,b)

c.simple_bind(a=(5, 10))
```
understood now. i'm agree that adding a shape attribution is cleaner than the possible solution that passes additional shape info to the data iterator

I guess dont broadcast unless you have to and chiyuan's example still works.

@piiswrong My problem is that I know that the expected behavior is to be shared. For example, if I want to implement the fully connected layer with low level arithmetics, I could say `out = matmul(X, W) + b`, here `b` should not be of shape `N-by-d`, instead it should be broadcast and have the shape `1-by-d` or just `(d, )`.

It is less advised to create two variables with the same name as input to the same graph, because sometimes binding operation depends on the naming. It is totally fine to use same name in two different graphs

this issue does not belongs to this project
You are Thanks for reporting this. It is now fixed

It is different definition of the output objective. 
For logistic regression, it is per element loss, so label shape equals the output shape. 
For softmax, the label gives the index of the class, so it is always batch_size
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification
have no idea where this comes from, as it is not part of the code base
@mli is working on a series of broadcast functions now c.f. #2039
you might want to disable CUDNN and RTC, as they might not be supporting 32 bit?
Usually you want to use SyncCopyToCPU instead. Note that NDArray represents an asynchronize computation object, whose content may not be available then
If you want to use RMSE as objective, you will want to add a LinearRegressionOutput on top of your final layer
SoftmaxOutput takes label index, so if you set batch_size equals 1, you should provide labels in shape (1,), as in the error message
@piiswrong is it possible for us to make a quick fix on this?
